detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Archaeology is a field of anthropology that studies past societies, their practices, and behaviors as inferred through the analysis of their material and biological remains. This course explores how archaeologists develop knowledge of the past, and how this knowledge is continuously questioned and improved upon. Archaeologists do not provide “final answers”; our understandings change as the kinds of questions we ask and the methods we use change. However, while there may be no “right” answer, there are better and worse ones — ones with more or less supporting evidence. Students will become familiar with the field of archaeology and with all phases of the research process.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is an in-person course. Students are expected to meet in-person on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘in-person’ are fully in-person for the entire term, including exams, and require in-person attendance to complete.
Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

instances.text: ASIA_V 110-021 - Introduction to Religions in Asia

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value:
Delivery Mode -This is a synchronous online course. Students are expected to meet online using Zoom on the days and times listed. All courses labelled as ‘online’ are fully online for the entire term, including exams, and do NOT require any in-person attendance to complete.

Waitlist Policy -All waitlists will follow a first come, first serve policy, unless specified otherwise. Once a course is full, its status will be changed to “Waitlist” and students who register will be automatically added to the waitlist.

ASTR_V 102-201 - Introduction to Stars and Galaxies

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Note: Students having completed Physics 12 are also eligible for ASTR 102. If, however, you experience difficulty in registering, please contact the undergraduate program coordinator at ugcoord@phas.ubc.ca. Registration in a Lab is mandatory. If you are registered in the lecture and need assistance, please contact ugcoord@phas.ubc.ca. Please do not remove yourself from a Lab, once registered in one.

ATSC_V 113-99C - Weather Science for Sailing, Flying, and Snow Sports

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: ATSC 113 is a hybrid, asynchronous course for all students.  All course content is available directly on the course website or through links to outside resources. There is no textbook for this course. All Quizzes and Assignments are open over a set number of days for students to complete when it fits best within their own schedule. These are then submitted online, through the Course Website. There are no lectures to attend or video lectures to follow. The only time students need to attend a session in-person is for the written final exam. The final exam will be written during the UBC exam period, at a time and date arranged by UBC Exam Services. All students will attend the final exam in-person in a UBC classroom.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Students may only register for one required course activity per lecture/lab/discussion or waitlist if there is no space available. Students will be removed from the waitlist if they already have a spot in a section of the course. For example, students may not register for BIOL121 section 121 and also be on the waitlist for section 122. BEING ON THE WAITLIST DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU A SPACE IN THE COURSE.

detailResultFields.label: Course Section Definition Public Notes
detailResultFields.value: Students may only register for one required course activity per lecture/lab/discussion or waitlist if there is no space available. Students will be removed from the waitlist if they already have a spot in a section of the course.  For example, students may not register for multiple labs or tutorials, including their respective waitlists.  BEING ON THE WAITLIST DOES NOT GUARANTEE YOU A SPACE IN THE LECTURE, LAB, OR TUTORIAL.

uiLabels.WDRES.FACETEDSEARCH.SymanSyntax:
Boolean logic can be expressed using AND, OR, NOT, and (). 
Exact phrases can be surrounded by double quotation marks. 
Example: ("software engineer" OR computer science) AND ~manager~.
